title: A Confession finale leaves viewers fuming over 'smug' killer Halliwell as he's sentenced

A Confession viewers were glued to the final scenes of the murder drama but the courtroom scenes left them seething with anger.

Christopher Halliwell was taken to trial for the murder of Becky Godden following his life sentence for killing Sian O'Callaghan, after police found extra evidence to charge him.

The trial scenes played out in the final minutes of the ITV series, showing Halliwell cross-examine Steve Fulcher himself with many viewers saying his "smug" nature made their "skin crawl".

Despite the tense scenes those watching praised actor Joe Absolom for his convincing turn as the evil killer.

(Image: ITV)

Halliwell confronted Fulcher in the courtroom much to the anger of the people inside and those watching at home.

"That court room scene made my skin crawl, the attitude, the smugness. Awful that this is based on true events," wrote one user on Twitter .

"Oh I’m getting so angry," fumed another.

"My insides are twisted up, I feel so angry, I want to scream," said one after witnessing the frustrating scenes.

(Image: ITV)

"Omg I can’t believe this went on in a courtroom," pointed out another about the drama that is based on real-life events.

Despite playing an evil killer, others praised the actor's turn on screen: "Joe Absolom’s portrayal of Christopher Halliwell is bloody incredible. His mannerisms are so accurate it hurts. What an underrated actor."

"But what a bloody good actor Joe Absolom is!!" gushed another.

"#AConfession so good!!! #joeabsolom is such a great actor, not on TV enough," added a third.

The gripping murder drama has told the real-life tragic stories of Sian O’Callaghan and Becky Godden-Edwards, both killed by evil Christopher Halliwell, and the detective who battled to bring him to justice.

The series, starring Martin Freeman as Det Supt Steve Fulcher and Imelda Staunton as Becky’s mum Karen, has captivated viewers.

The one off series has followed detective Steve Fulcher's investigation into the death and disappearance of 22-year-old Sian, from Swindon, in 2011 who days later was discovered murdered.

(Image: ITV)

In the court scenes Halliwell abstained from the use of counsel and opted to cross-examine a former prostitute who he had slept with and provided damning evidence against him over the murder of Becky Godden.

He attempted to shoot down her version of events claiming he hadn't slept with either of them when evidence proved otherwise.

It was as former detective superintendent Steve Fulcher took the stand that angered viewers.

(Image: SWNS.com)

(Image: PA Archive/PA Images)

Halliwell brutally assassinated Fulcher with baseless claims and pointed out the mistakes he had made that led to him being terminated by the police force.

"It was a pleasure ruining your career you corrupt b*****d," the killer uttered with a smirk.

But the prosecution team poked holes in Halliwell's claims and were able to bring a guilty verdict from the judge who sentenced him to a second life term.

The real Christopher Halliwell, who has three children with his ex-wife Lisa, remains locked up in the Category A HMP Long Lartin in Worcestershire.

He is likely to die behind bars without ever being eligible for parole.
description: Viewers said the courtroom scenes had their 'skin crawling' but praised actor Joe Absolom for his convincing turn
